dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Canelo Alvarez is kicking off his new ESPN deal at the Staples Center on January 15th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Canelo Alvarez is kicking off his new E S P N deal at the Staples Center on January fifteenth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alvarez will kick off his DAZN deal December 15 at Madison Square Garden against Rocky Fielding, and then likely fight again in early May for a Cinco de Mayo match.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh right, against Rocky Marciano, and it's part of that huge contract—what, like 37 million minimum?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh right, against Rocky Marciano, and it's part of that huge contract-what, like thirty seven million minimum?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The deal is worth a minimum of $365 million, an average of $33 million per fight, according to his promoter Golden Boy Promotions. Alvarez will kick off his DAZN deal December 15 at Madison Square Garden against Rocky Fielding, and then likely fight again in early May for a Cinco de Mayo match.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, an average of 30 million per fight. And that's just the start—with endorsements and his last Golovkin purse, he could clear 80 million this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, an average of thirty million per fight. And that's just the start-with endorsements and his last Golovkin purse, he could clear eighty million this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With the two DAZN fights, plus roughly $50 million for his razor-thin win over Gennady Golovkin last month and several million dollars from endorsements, Alvarez should bank at least $120 million over the 12 months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Eighty million? That's wild. But wait, didn't the article mention he might still rank as one of the lowest-paid athletes next year?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eighty million? That's wild. But wait, didn't the article mention he might still rank as one of the lowest-paid athletes next year?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Mexican boxer has a strong chance to rank as the worlds highest-paid athlete next year in Forbes annual look at the top stars in sports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, which is kinda mind-blowing. Forbes' list includes some massive earners—Mbappé, Ronaldo, LeBron…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, which is kinda mind-blowing. Forbes' list includes some massive earners-Mbappé, Ronaldo, LeBron...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cristiano Ronaldo, Neymar, LeBron James, Aaron Rodgers and Roger Federer are also expected to earn at least $90 million toward next year's list, which will include prize money, salaries and bonuses earned between June 1, 2018, and June 1, 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he used to be with Showtime, right? They had all those legends—Mayweather, Pacquiao…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he used to be with Showtime, right? They had all those legends-Mayweather, Pacquiao...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: HBO was the former home for Alvarez, who ranks as the biggest pay-per-view star in the sport after the retirement of Floyd Mayweather.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but his deal there ended after the GGG loss. Now ESPN's stepping up big time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but his deal there ended after the G G G loss. Now E S P N's stepping up big time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alvarezs deal with HBO ended after his win over GGG.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it's a historic deal for boxing, but did you catch that quote from Alvarez? He said it'll make him prepare less and give worse performances?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it's a historic deal for boxing, but did you catch that quote from Alvarez? He said it'll make him prepare less and give worse performances?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Being part of this historic deal will require me to prepare myself even more and offer fans even better performances, Alvarez said in a release announcing the deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, that was… interesting thing to say in a press release. Maybe taken out of context? Or just honest, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, that was... interesting thing to say in a press release. Maybe taken out of context? Or just honest, I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Either way, the money's staggering. His per-fight average is on par with Pacquiao's old Fox deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Either way, the money's staggering. His per-fight average is on par with Pacquiao's old Fox deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And way above some other sports contracts—like Shohei Ohtani's, or even global soccer stars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And way above some other sports contracts-like Shohei Ohtani's, or even global soccer stars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global soccer icons Neymar and Lionel Messi both have deals worth roughly $350 million, with Neymars a five-year contract and Messis haul spread over four years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, competing with Mbappé for the 'lowest-paid' title… puts things in perspective. The scale in top-tier boxing is just different.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, competing with Mbappé for the 'lowest-paid' title... puts things in perspective. The scale in top-tier boxing is just different.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Mexican boxer has a strong chance to rank as the worlds highest-paid athlete next year in Forbes annual look at the top stars in sports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And with ESPN now in the mix, the landscape's shifting fast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And with E S P N now in the mix, the landscape's shifting fast.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alvarez will kick off his DAZN deal December 15 at Madison Square Garden against Rocky Fielding, and then likely fight again in early May for a Cinco de Mayo match.

artist_script:
HostA: Canelo Alvarez is kicking off his new ESPN deal at the Staples Center on January 15th.
HostB: Oh right, against Rocky Marciano, and it’s part of that huge contract—what, like 37 million minimum?
HostA: Yeah, an average of 30 million per fight. And that’s just the start—with endorsements and his last Golovkin purse, he could clear 80 million this year.
HostB: Eighty million? That’s wild. But wait, didn’t the article mention he might still rank as one of the lowest-paid athletes next year?
HostA: Exactly, which is kinda mind-blowing. Forbes’ list includes some massive earners—Mbappé, Ronaldo, LeBron…
HostB: And he used to be with Showtime, right? They had all those legends—Mayweather, Pacquiao…
HostA: Yeah, but his deal there ended after the GGG loss. Now ESPN’s stepping up big time.
HostB: I mean, it’s a historic deal for boxing, but did you catch that quote from Alvarez? He said it’ll make him prepare less and give worse performances?
HostA: Uh, yeah, that was… interesting thing to say in a press release. Maybe taken out of context? Or just honest, I guess.
HostB: Either way, the money’s staggering. His per-fight average is on par with Pacquiao’s old Fox deal.
HostA: And way above some other sports contracts—like Shohei Ohtani’s, or even global soccer stars.
HostB: Still, competing with Mbappé for the ‘lowest-paid’ title… puts things in perspective. The scale in top-tier boxing is just different.
HostA: For sure. And with ESPN now in the mix, the landscape’s shifting fast.
